Method Detail

binomi

public static double binomi(double a,
                            int k)
binomi calculates the number of possibilities to choose k Elements out of a. in German: (k aus a) oder (a über k). Frequently needed to calculate probabilities when taking samples.

Parameters:
a - the total number of elements to choose from.
k - the sample size
Returns:
binomial coefficient

gamma

public static double gamma(double x)
The Gamma Function extends the fak (!) to fractional values. It is defined for all numbers that are no negative integer.

Parameters:
x - argument of the gamma function.
Returns:
value of the gamma function (or NaN, if not defined)

hyperGeomet

public static double hyperGeomet(int pool,
                                 int def_in_pool,
                                 int def_in_sample,
                                 int sample_size)
The hypergeometric distribution function hyperGeomet gives the probability to get def_in_sample defective parts in a sample.

Parameters:
pool - the total number of parts.
def_in_pool - the total number of defective parts.
def_in_sample - the number of defective parts in the sample.
sample_size - the sample size.
Returns:
hypergeometric distribution function.

binDistrib

public static double binDistrib(int n,
                                int x,
                                double p)
binDistrib calculates the binomial distribution function. This is the probability for maximal x defective parts in a given sample where the percentage p of defectives is known. Must be used for quantitative (counting) probes if the number of defectives per sample is considered.

Parameters:
n - The sample size
x - The maximum number of defectives in the sample.
p - The percentage of defectives (0.1 = 10%)
Returns:
The binomial distribution function

binZSB

public static CSysInterval binZSB(double p,
                                  double alpha,
                                  int type,
                                  int n)
binZSB calculates the Interval for the binomial distribution, where the observed percentage of defective parts is to expect for a given samplesize, total percentage of defective parts and error probability.

Parameters:
p - the total percentage of defective parts
n - the samplesize
alpha - the error probability ]0..1.0[
type - ZWEISEITIG (both sides open interval) EINSEITIG_OBEN (one side open interval) EINSEITIG_UNTEN (one side open interval)
Returns:
interval

binVB

public static CSysInterval binVB(int x,
                                 int n,
                                 double alpha,
                                 int type)
If a sample with a given sample size n has been taken, x of n of the parts being defective. This method calculates the possible range of the percentage of overal defective parts. Note: this range can only be calculated to a given error probability i.e. if you want to be absolutely sure, the returned interval will get infinite. On the other hand, if an error of 100% is accepted, the interval has no span, upper and lower interval boundaries will exactly be x/n.

Parameters:
x - the number of defective parts in the sample.
n - the sample size
alpha - the error probability (double)
type - the type of calculation ZWEISEITIG
Returns:
the possible range of the percentage of overal defective parts

poissonDistrib

public static double poissonDistrib(int x,
                                    double my)
Deprecated. Use poisson() with the same signature in this class.

poissonDistrib calculates the poisson distribution function. This is the probability for maximal x defects per part(unit), where my, the average number of defectives per part(unit) is known. Must be used for quantitative (counting) probes if the number of defectives per part is considered.

Parameters:
x - The minimum number of defectives in the sample.
my - The percentage of defectives (0.1 = 10%)
Returns:
The poisson distribution function

poisson

public static double poisson(int k,
                             double x)
Returns the sum of the first k terms of the Poisson distribution. This is the probability for maximal k defects per part(unit), where x, the average number of defectives per part(unit) is known. Must be used for quantitative (counting) probes if the number of defectives per part is considered.

Parameters:
k - number of terms, The minimum number of defectives in the sample.
x - double value The percentage of defectives (0.1 = 10%)
Returns:
The poisson distribution function

poissonc

public static double poissonc(int k,
                              double x)
Returns the sum of the terms k+1 to infinity of the Poisson distribution.

Parameters:
k - start
x - double value
Returns:
cumulative Poisson distribution.

gFunction

public static double gFunction(double u)
Calculates the Standard Distribution Function G. This is an Algorithm published in Timischl 353; it is based on the Taylor expansion around 0.5

Parameters:
u - normalized argument (x-mue)/sigma of the Distribution Function
Returns:
Standard Distribution Function as a double
See Also:
the inverse function.

uFunction

public static double uFunction(double g)
Will calculate the inverse of the Standard Distribution Function. This is an Algorithm published in Timischl 353; it is based on a Polynom The author claims, error is < 1/1000 We found this is a better approximation as uFunction2

Parameters:
g - value of distribution function (0..1) as a double.
Returns:
u normalized argument (x-mue)/sigma of the Distribution Function
See Also:
the inverse function.

gammqFunction

public static double gammqFunction(int f,
                                   double chi2)
The Incomplete Gamma Function see Chapter 6.2 of the "numericals recipes in C" about Incomplete Gamma Function, Error Function, Chi-Square Probability Function, Cumulative Poisson Function for a description of this method.

Parameters:
f - The degree of freedom.
chi2 - parameter of the Incomplete Gamma Function
Returns:
gammq

chiCritical

public static double chiCritical(int f,
                                 double g)
Critical values of the Chi2 distribution. The critical values are defined as the upper limits of an integration. Do not try the following to calculate chiCritical (it is a bad example): 

	double summe=0;
	double x=0;
	double fak=1.0/Math.pow(2.0,f/2.0)/gamma(f/2.0);
	fak*=EPSILON;
	while (summe<G) // Take sum, until probability sum  is reached
	{
	  x+=EPSILON;
	  summe+=fak*Math.pow(x,f/2.0-1.0)*Math.exp(-x/2.0);
	}
	return x;

Parameters:
f - "Freiheitsgrad" usually this is sample_size minus 1.
g - probability sum (1-alpha)
Returns:
Critical value of the Chi2 distribution.

student2

public static double student2(float v,
                              double p)
Student's t Critical values (percentage points) Abramowitz & Stegun formula 26.7.5 this is a bad approximation of the reverse function of tprobability. We can only use this as a guessing function.

Parameters:
v - Freiheitgrad
p - probability sum
Returns:
The student distribution critical values.

invz

public static double invz(double pp)
Inverse Normal Distribution. Abramowitz & Stegun formula 26.2.23

Parameters:
pp - The percentage of distribution
Returns:
The Inverse Normal Distribution

wCritical

public static double wCritical(int n,
                               double percentage)
Calculate critical value of the w-distribution. This is the value, where the probability sum of the w-distribution reaches a given percentage. This function is hard to find even as a table in the literature. See DGQ Table 16 (taken from Biometrica Trust 1976); Description DGQ G4.5-4 G4.5-10. To calculate the rangelimits, the result of this function has to be multiplicated by sigma. precision of returned values will be 0.001 i.e 0.1%

Parameters:
n - The samplesize
percentage - The propability sum out of the Interval ]0.0; 1.0[.
Returns:
critical value of the w-distribution
See Also:
if you need the distribution function

tprobability

public static double tprobability(int dof,
                                  double t)
Student's t distribution probability (lower tail). Algorithm AS 3 from Applied Statistics (1968) Vol. 17, p. 189. Fortran source from statlib, translated by f2c, cleaned up A LOT by hand by Ajay Shah, Sun May 5 03:48:17 PDT 1991 This functional interface is not exactly what AS 3 used to be. Transfered to Java by hh returns probability now instead of referencing double *probability

Parameters:
dof - degrees of freedom of this t distribution.
t - argument for the integral from t to +infinity.
Returns:
computed value of probability.
